transc: Yet I cant imagine why thee wants so many small quantities of double [zephyr].  I believe they do not [sell] it in less than half [an] [gr.] of an oz.  We wish endeavor to get the other things.  Mother has told you what the prospects are about coming Do'nt expect her on 7th day, for I do not think there is much probability of her getting off.  Edgar & I may stay a week longer but I shall not consent to stay long.  Am going to take tea at Dr [Morris] with Cos Sarah is'nt it [awful].  With love to [Father] & Love Ever yr sister C

transc:
that I can sew them on. I wish if you shd. have any opportunity you wld. send me my old blk silk body wh. hangs in the back room closet. Tammy Miller is going to P tomorrow & out to Mary Morris’ so I told her to tell you that she saw the school “mam” Give my love to Cousin Frank & Mary Tell Cousin Mary I had the pleasure of seeing her mother & I think her father yesterday. Give my love to Cous. Sarah & to Tom & Harry & to all Aunt Carolines & any other enquiring frds.
I have written you a lengthy epistle I hope there’ll be an exception in favor of mistakes & bad writing as I have written lying on my back I was so very tired this morning that I was too lazy to sit up. I do not get much time to [sun] as my room is too cold to sit in & they do not seem to bring their sewing into the parlor much. With much love

Your affec
Sister C

I am going to send you a drawing of my house when I get time so you can imagine how things are a little better. I hope Edgar will get the drafting business all settled, satisfactorily

title: 1911 June 29, Dundale, to Alg
additi: Evans, Ernest Mervyn, 1884-1911
subjec: Condolence notes;  Bereavement--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Death
notes:
Watermark: “Holland linen”

Algernon’s brother, Ernest Mervyn Evans, died on June 28 after being injured in a subway accident.

Joseph Morris wrote the letter from Dundale, the Morris family estate in Villanova. Now part of the university’s campus, the mansion was erected in 1890 as a retreat from the city for Israel Morris’s son Theodore (who had just attained the presidency of Morris & Wheeler, his father’s iron company) and his many children. The building currently houses the development offices of Villanova University.

All information from Stokes’ Stokes Cope Emlen Evans Genealogy (1982), the printed eulogy of Ernest Mervyn Evans, and various Villanova University websites. A picture of Dundale may be found online at www.villanova.edu/maps/bldgs/dundale.htm.

notes:
Letter is from the steamer Dalmatia. Stationery bears crest in blue with the word“Vorwaerts” (forward, in German) under an anchor and crown. Underneath crest are the words “Oesterreichischer Lloyd. Triest.” Large watermark depicting a crown and the words “Imperial Century.”

The city of Acre was captured by King Philip Augustus of France and King Richard the Lion-Hearted of England during the Third Crusade (1189-1192).

Bakshish, stemming from the Persian for “to give,” means to tip.

The stories of Tabitha, Simon the Tanner, and Peter’s vision are from Acts 9:26-10:15. Peter raised Tabitha (also called Dorcas), a charitable woman, from the dead in the town of Joppa. He stayed there at the home of Simon the Tanner (today the house is open for visitors), where he had his vision of animals trapped in a sheet, which the Lord bade him to eat. When he refused, protesting that the Lord had designated some of them unclean for consumption, the Lord replied, “What God hath cleansed, make not thou common.” Following this vision, Peter visited a Gentile named Cornelius and widened the scope of Christian ministry (then practiced within Judaism, as it was considered unclean for a Jew to minister to a Gentile) to include those outside the Jewish faith.

Sydney, Nova Scotia, is located on the island of Cape Breton. Known as “the Steel City,” Sydney is the third largest city in the province of Nova Scotia and is home to the Dominion Steel and Coal Company. A number of railway lines travel through Sydney.

transc:
Washington February 11th. 1852.

Dear Father,
I have been most impatiently detained here, a very long time; but 'the long agony' will soon be over. The causes which I came to argue were reached yesterday, when Morris commenced & concluded his speech. St. Geo. I. Campbell & G. M. Dallas followed this morning, & have occupied the entire session with speeches of two hours each.- I am to reply tomorrow.
Our cases happened to be [near] several important cases on the List & among them next to the Gaines case, which, from the mass of evidence contained in the Record, occupied about ten days. It would have been deemed imprudent to be absent, during the progress of that argument, as owing to the stringency of the Rules in the Supreme Court and the rigor with which they are enforced, if from any accident, the sickness of Counsel or otherwise, the discussion had been shortened & our cases had been reached during our absence, they would have been stricken from the Calendar.
Among the numerous listeners who throng this Court, Anthony Morris has been in attendance, to hear what could be said in the federal forum against the validity of a Law

transc:
of Penna., which he had assisted to enact, as a member of its Senate. This was happily alluded to by Dallas, in the course of his speech, to-day. Thee will remember that he is the grandfather of P. P. Morris, & was Speaker of our Senate in 1803, when the pilot Law was passed.- Dallas, in commenting upon the antiquity of the legislation, which it is his object to sustain, and ours to overthrow, as unconstitutional, remarked that we were growing wiser than our fathers. He observed that the first act on the Statute Book of Penna., in relation to pilot age, was that passed by the Provincial Assembly of 1766, and that the act of 1803 which contained its leading provisions, succeeded it, & was authenticated by the name of a gentleman, now nearly 90 years of age. He saw his venerable form, now among his audience, enter the Court room yesterday, for the purpose of listening to the speech of his Grandson, who after the lapse of nearly 50 years, was trying to undermine the work to which his grandfather's name was attached, as the presiding officer of the Senate, & have it declared unconstitutional.
The allusion, which was happily introduced, was a good point, & [created] an impression in favor of the side he espoused. The dignified C. Justice, having his curiosity excited as to the person referred to, leaned forward in his flowing gown, to enquire, almost in a whisper, to whom the Hon. speaker alluded. Awbury.
Sept. 20. 1889.

My dear Lilly. I know that thee has thought it strange that I have never written to thee all summer. but one thing and another always turned up. & [---] the days go by without doing so – now that I really have something to tell thee perhaps it won’t be so hard! but I wont go on like Elliston Morris – but will get to the point of my tale which is simply that I am engaged to Will Lewis! The engagement is not to be announced for a long time yet – This is especially

transc:
hints as above, and would have thee to use them or not, only as way may open--Indeed I can quite believe that, if a fitting, natural opening does not occur, it may be best to speak to Anna of nothing beyond my continued loving interest in her.
As to the results of our own rambling, I may thankfully say that, for myself, there seems a marked gain in several respects, but, as thou has intimated, the full benefit of such changes is sometimes felt later. My dear Hannah could scarcely be in better condition for enjoying to the full the scenes of rare interest and beauty thr'o which we are and have been passing. I think however, we shall both be glad when the time for our return voyage shall have come. This will be 10/5, by the "Haverford", for Phila, and shortly after, if the Lord will, we may hope to be once more among our dear home friends--Please remember us in love to Jon., while I remain

very sincerely thy friend
Sam Morris

was the Mother of the Dentist Elisha K. Townsend who founded the Philada. Dental College–) "Let me number my blessings!"– And another saying of an old Irish neighbor we had – who had many trials & sorrows – but would end up her stories with – "but sure, Welcome be the Will of the Lord!"–
– But I am too reminiscent for young people, & this letter is terribly egotistic, so I will stop but your kindness & dear Annette’s letter have brought back many delightful memories.– The years are rapidly rolling by, & I have now entered my eightieth. –
Good bye,– with dear love to you both & many thanks I remain
your old friend
S. T. Morris –

transc:
afflicted in that way. – The strongest point in my memory about them – is your father’s good sound "orthodox" dignity – always so cheerily smoothed over, by your Mother’s beautiful almost angelic smile which brightened almost everybody & everything around them. – I don’t wonder he went to bed, when she was taken from him, & could never be persuaded to rise again. – I must close this now for my messenger to take to the post office. –

— How I do wish you would come to see us. I hardly know any one who would be more welcome. – Now, think it over & see if you can’t come,– particularly if a cold wave strikes Germantown. —

Good bye – in which both my girls join, – don’t ever doubt me, but believe me always your loving & affectionate friend
Sibylla T. Morris.

transc:
Newport 8mo 25. 1840

Dear Alfred,

It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.- You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere- Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before. The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty- Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM- We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here- We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM- We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c. & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-

We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes- The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited- We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries- On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"- The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much

As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-

better? I cannot help hoping she will be entirely herself
again before very long.- Their house is very bright &
pleasant & I should think they might be very happy there-
This to be sure happiness is not a thing of outward
circumstances [----]

than any she ever attended before. I loved that school very much & whenever I think of it, always see, in my minds eye,- thee & Julia & Clemmy coming in - & going to the cloak room.-

transc:
Not very long ago to be up some time before breakfast and desire very much to get back into the habit and intend to when I begin to practice my preaching's to thee on this and other matters.

I will not believe that thee is not fond of rambling about the woods until I have a chance of cross-questioning thee about it. I dare say it would turn out that it was being overtired that thee does not enjoy.

I believe I have not much family or other news to send thee. Aunt Caroline has been kept to her bed for some time, but is getting better. Mary I suppose thee knows was at the sea shore with us. Aunt Rebecca and son James B. are pretty much well. Grandfather continues very well for him and seems contented and comfortable at Uncle Alfred's. Our [] families both great and small members are almost as usual. Is Mary Anne Morris a sort of cousin to thine? If she is, thee will have to make a little room in the place when thee keeps thy cousins, for Sandy Martin.

Now Clemmy thee will agree with me that this is not an interesting letter. That is what I never did and never expect to write and thee must not take it as any measure of my good will toward thee. If I had followed my inclination it would have been written very soon after I got thine, and I hope thee will find time amid thy household cares, if this finds thee still at the head of affairs to answer it very soon. I send Elizabeth love on my own responsibility and if I was at Germantown should have various such messages for thee. If I have not replied to every thing in thy

transc:
Woodbourne 7 month 13th 1829
Dear Brother:

Thine of 29th ult. has been rece'd. I was pleased to learn that our parents were well, and hope that Edward & Alfred may be benefited by their proposed excursion and that thou may’st also find time to enjoy ye benefits of ye same kind of recreation. Ye country is now enlivened by visitors from ye City and Susquehanna Co. is favoured with a share of them. James Holly Biddle bro't back with them from Phila. their sisters Sarah Biddle and Mary Drinker, and E. Walker's family have ye company of ye widow Morris, and her daughters, Susan & Elizabeth. We have lately been favoured also with a visit from Joel Woolman and Alvin Keyser, appointed by Abington Quarterly Meeting to visit Friendsville Preparative Meeting. they appeared to be man of plain, unassuming humble manners, and were well received by both Hicksites & Orthodox. Cha's Shoemaker accompanied them as far as a Stroudsburg, where he became so ill, as to present his proceeding further. We have subsequently had a visit from Ja's Bell, another orthodox friend and an elder, appointed by Stroudsburg Monthly Meeting.

Dan'l Stroud has been indisposed, or he also wd. probably have visited this part of his flock. he occasionally writes excellent letters of advice to afford thee an idea of his decisive and at the same time affectionate letters of language & manner, I will give thee an extract from one of them, recently addressed to E. Walker: "distressing as is ye fact, yet it certainly is the case, that the Hicksites are a distinct Society from Friends, and ye separation proceeded from ye leaders of that seccession having become corrupted with anti-christian doctrines, mostly Socinian, but compounded with some other speculative notions, made up into bills to suit ye subjects to whom they were to be administered, and gilt with specious professions of great spirituality, to captivate members and professors with Friends. this with various practices, such as are too commonly used in electioneering, have beguiled & seduced many, who have not or had not previously embraced those awfully dreadful notions, not fitting to be styled doctrines, when we are speaking of religion, and whether these will become leavened into the mass of infidelity with their leaders, or separate from them remains among the things which futurity must disclose. that thou & I, and ye dear children Providentially entrusted to our care, may be preserved from this direful contagion, I have earnestly craved, feeling some hope, that we may resist every temptation that may beset us, to unsettle us and loss about with every wind of doctrine.

If we ever knew anything, "as we ought to know", le us "walk by ye same rule and mind the same thing." Let us be satisfied with and established in "the faith once delivered to ye saints",

transc:
Woodbourne 9 month 2. 1830
Dear Brother:

The kind sympathy expressed in thy letter of 25 ult. for the loss of my buildings etc, was very grateful. I have become, as I hoped wd. be the case when I last wrote, much better reconciled to my loss than I then was. I occasionally leave a sigh as I pass by ye remains of a beautiful rosebush or shrub, on which I have often looked with sensation of pleasures, now reduced to a black & unsightly stem, or a fine fruit tree, scathed & withered by ye scorching heat. But my feelings seem to become settled under ye conviction, that regrets are vain & useless, for what cannot be restored. The joint invitation of thyself & Rachel to G. Walker was very acceptable both to him & the family. He hesitated to accept it, on account of not being personally acquainted with thee, but, upon further consideration, desired me to express his thanks to you, & to say that he wd. accept it, though he expected that most of his leisure time, when not occupied with attention to his duties as an Anti-Masonic delegate, wd. he divided amongst his relatives & friends. He expects to leave here in ye stage on ye morning of ye 8th, & to reach Philada. on ye evening of ye 9th [inst]. I feel glad that he has concluded to accept of your kind offer, shall consider myself indebted for any little kind offices done for him, or services rendered, & will credit you for them as if performed for myself. I think ye members of E. Walker's family, are of real benefit in promoting & advancing ye interest of this Country, or of this part of it. They seem to serve as pioneers for ye better classes of society, & consequently ye more desriable kind of population. their extensive correspondence & acquaintance brings ye country into notice, & their hospitality to those who visit it, creates an impression in its favour. They at present have 6 of their relatives with them as guests , from Philada. & Wynne Wood, in ye neighourhood of ye City: Mary Jones, whose beautiful & wealthy daughter was lately married to Levi, son of Israel W. Morris, her son, Levi & his bride, the widow Jones, Mother of Stephenson & Cornelius Smith, and her grandson. This

transc:
Germantown, 9.30.83.

My Dear Carrie-
I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptable, even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.

I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasure, no doubt, though mingled with sadness, to Nettie & thee, to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.

The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him well, yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel Morris, who rode in the same carriage

transc:
Thee sus I am still here at Woodbourne, "done took root an' set out shoop" as my old Mammie would say, but Mrs. Cope was good enough to ask me to stay a few days longer to meet Miss Morris, who came up with her brother and Mr. Scattergood yesterday afternoon. We are the silliest crowd they ever saw, Frank looks at Evylin and they both burst into a perfect fit of laughter, then Mr. Scatterfood brings up the rear with a ringing [---] . Then they look at each other and ask "Whats' the matter?" and all three answer "It’s Joe's Fault". Poor Joe, they make day hidious to him. That the way we go on all the time and Mrs. Cope is filled with dispair.

So you really did have the picnic at the camp. I didn't think the

evening Ed & I went over to a small party at the Whitalls. Greta had home Marion Lane who is in her class and had asked Letitia Wright the Emlens, Jay Brown & Billy Kimber to come over. We had a very nice time tho nothing at all thrilling. On our way over I picked up a $10 gold piece on Church Lane in front of the Storks! I have never had any luck that way before & could hardly believe my eyes. I looked for any advertisements for it but could find none. On 1st day I enquired I enquired of them at Church Lane but none of them had lost any money. I asked Henry if Morris Bockins had lost anything as I thought he might carry some gold but Henry had not heard of him losing anything. In the afternoon therefore Ed & I started over to

transc: Boltons to advertise the Ledger but left doing it on our way over as the boy at Boltons said it did not have to be sent before 5.30 to get in 2nd days paper.  When we got over to the Stokes Henry announced that the owner of my $10 was a poor woman in Irishtown.  I thought he was only kidding but he said that he had seen Morris Bockins after meeting & had asked him whether he had lost any money.  Mr B. said that he had not lost any directly but a poor boy who was coming over to his house from Irishtown with the [---], had been unable to curb his curiosity to look at the money which his mother had given him & his looking at it had dropped a $10 gold piece which he had search diligently for but had been unable to find where upon he was so much over came that he had run home at once.  The next morning his mother had come over & told how her son had lost the money & that her husband had looked for it very early the next morning but had been unable to find it & that consequently she could pay her rent.  The poor woman he said was very much broken up about her loss.  As these facts entirely agreed with what I knew

transc: Hazen had to rush out a couple times to see the cause of the rumpus and now he has put them down in the cellar and because they are quiet now thinks he has solved the problem of keeping them quiet!  I have my doubts but am not saying anything just yet a while.  Grandpa and Uncle T. did not come down today after all.  Uncle Hazen received a telegram today saying that they would be down on 4th day.  I rather expect that Uncle Hazens stage party which comes off tomorrow night has rather discouraged them tho I dont know anything about it.  I did nothing during thr 4th except go over to Ros[---] in the evening and see them send off a lot of fireworks which were very good considering they were private.  The Goodhue kids were great sports.  Little [---] nearly turned inside out when a rocket or bomb went off.  On 7th day I took a Sabbath day journey out to Moorestown and played cricket which turned out desasterously to us as we were beaten 162 to 50 of which I made 10.  I stayed out at Moorestown with Stodgell Stokes to supper and had a very pleasant visit with them.  I had never been there before and enjoyed seeing them much.  Dr & Mrs Stokes inquired after you all.  I had intended to get out to Joes Morris' to stay over 1st day but I could not get in town in time to get out to Villa Nova before very late so I came home.  On 1st day I went to Frank Goodhues to dinner and in the evening went to Emlens to supper.  On 6th day Evening I went down to Shoemakers to see Anna & Frank Fortunately they were at home and I had a very nice visit.  Tomorrow Anna Hacker, Mary Jones, Annie Williams, Frank Stokes, Frank Strawbridge & myself are going up to Willow Grove.  I guess we will have pretty good time.  Tell Ed that I tried to get

when they saw her. She had a bad night and in the morning the Dr said she had pneumonia and did not look for her to recover. I do not know how she took cold.

I have been having a great deal going on in a special way lately so that I have not had a chance to do all the things I have wanted to do,- one of which was to may Joe Morris a visit. Alf & Henry are out there now but Joe & Ev go up to Woodbourne [---] about the 1st. I have not time to write more at present. Things certainly have kept moving this summer & I have had a mighty good time. We are all very well. Please give my love to Anna, with lots for thyself I am as ever thine
Algernon

transc:
that Ell has been right sick having had an attack of Gripp and there after getting better having a relapse from which I think she is now recovering. It is too bad that she should have been sick just as this time, especially as they are getting ready to move. but it is a good thing that Aunt L is down there to look after them. To continue the health bulletin- Father seems to be pretty well and cheerful tho his ankle does not seem to get much better tho he [---] it. He drives a great deal and occassionally goes out to supper & dinner (I dont know how much he goes out to dinner). We have not had very much company in the evening tho Davis came up one night and Frank & Betty were over on 5th day night which Father enjoyed. I expect it would be good for him if we had some more company but it seems very hard to find a time when we have not got engagements.

Yesterday Joe Morris & I went up to the Rancocas and canoed. It was a very fine day in the morning and a pretty good

transc: damp & sticky.  No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hours, the close must have been very peaceful, both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering.  The funeral was small, so many are away, S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her character, there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweet, quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lights, everything looking so beautiful & peaceful, words did not seem to be needed. transc:
the change. William Newhall was there and he told me he was so glad his sisters had such a place to stay in and Abby and Mary both seems so glad they were when they were and not at a boarding house or hotel. They said it had seemed like home to them from the very first day they move out. I sent them some flowers on my way to meeting. They want me to be on hand at the time of the funeral to do some things for them so I shall go out in the 12 M train.

We had a good meeting this morning Cousin James and Samuel Morris spoke- Cousin James came to me after meeting and said they were so much obliged for our kindness to Anna &c- I am better dearest the pain

transc: up and since then we have been very little troubled with warm weather. Morris Fraln and his two sisters came on with us, and I was surprised to meet Gertrude and Lydia Cromwell at the Kensington depot- they had been making a visit in Phila. and were on their way home- We had a cloudy evening, and for a time it was quite rough- but as the night advanced the wind died away, and it became quite foggy; I waked up once- and heard the steam going off- and the boat had apparently stopped- Imagine my fright! I got up and looked out the window and found some men going backwards and forwards on deck with a rope- I could not tell for some time what was the matter but after a while I heard “Seventeen fathom, soft (or hard) bottom.” The necessity

[page damage] was rather alarming to me, but I suppose it is common in a fog. [page damage] went to sleep, after watching them for some time, and we reached Newport safely about five o’clock- It is very natural to be here again, and delightful to be so near Charles and Sue- some of the boarders are very pleasant, although I have not seen a great deal of some of them, yet. Deborah Wharton and her grand-children, the Thurstons- Susan Wharton and two children- Helty Smith and her three, and Lillie Parrish and Ben Smith when he is here (he spends his first days here) make quite a large party of themselves- then George Randolph and his family, the Fralns, Wistar Morris’s party, some people named Ames, with Edward Earle and his family and ourselves make up our family at present. Edward Earle, who is David Buffum’s son-in-law has the corner cottage which the

title: hsc1054_03
transc:
the procession at the cemetery he had to walk by himself and altogether it was very marked and unpleasant. Cous. Joseph did not get out. It was almost too much for Cous. Fanny, but I think she seems better this evening.

I have duly rec'd both thy letters and was very glad to get them and learn how everything was going on. I hope "Polly" (is that what thee is going to call her?) will prove a treasure of a nurse and relieve thee in caring for little Agnes. Don't get too tired and don't let the little girl have too much notice taken of her. Mrs. Morris told me of a whole family of children who died of brain disease produced by overexcitement when they were babies! She also says they should not have too great a variety of playthings and should learn to content themselves with simple amusements! The opposite plan makes them nervous and reckless. Perhaps thee

title: hsc0641_02
transc:
The action of our monthly meeting is a surprise to me and yet I must take it as a confirmation of the guidance of our dear Master.

If He calls for and accepts my imperfect service vocally I am humbled, yet grateful to Him.

Yet I want deliberate judgment upon the matter, & that when I make mistakes you will counsel me.

I am your friend sincerelyHannah P. Morris

title: hsc1230_02
transc: as Dr. Morris has seen it he knows best, uncle Harry said he could not tell certainly without seeing it. I went in town in the early cars & came out oat four yesterday. I was going to stay in & see the procession (wh. I suppose you have heard about) but suddenly remembered I hadn't studied a word of my lessons, so I had to hurry out of town in the 4 o'clock cars. I believe Aunt Sue is coming on next 7th day tho we have not been over there for several days but intend to go tomorrow. I believe Aunt Annie is writing to thee most likely to send her love, & thanks for your kind loves. Tell Tom we are

title: hsc0687_02
transc: also of your visit to “Jane Millar.” I should think you would have enjoyed the city of Edinboro, its surroundings & associations. I recall how much Uncle Charles & Aunt Emma enjoyed their visit to the Scotch city when they were over in 1870. FD & I have not heard anything about Carrie & Morris since they went to Montrose, but as we are having a warm summer (so far) they certainly will be glad they are not at Hampton, & on their mother’s account it will be much more healthful. Here we have only to be thankful we are not in a heated city or in the neighborhood of Phila. as there has been so very much warm dampness & continued from the 1st of this month with perhaps two or three cool days in each week, while here we can only occasionally wear linen dresses & have such delicious there we are often too cool. I fear Amy Cope & her family as well as Charles & Ellie have suffered from the humid atmosphere which has been more prevalent than usual in 7th month. On 6th day and yesterday we were thinking of Ellie preparing to sail & sailing for England on the 28th yesterday, we hope Ellie will realize a gain in strength by her voyage & visit in England. They have had plenty of time to consider the advisability of it, we have not heard from Anna Yarnall for 2 weeks. She & Miss Abbot & Fanny

title: hsc0687_04
transc: she is invited by Mary & Kate to make them a visit. She is a most appreciative person when she is so invited. She has been here when invited by Mary Perot. Perhaps you have not heard that Mary Cresson is spending the summer with Anne Morris, of course Anne misses her father greatly for tho’ he lived to be 90 (I think 94) his faculties were bright & he was a constant source for loving service & thought, & an aged member of the family is so much missed. We had an excellent sermon this morning in the parlor from a man who had been here other summers with his wife. I think they are Presbyterians and that they have both probably done much good work in a missionary spirit in Brooklyn, as well as the usual work & service of a member in his own Church. We have had very pleasant intercourse with them other years & were glad to see them come this year. There is also Bishop Andrews of N. York, with  his wife & daughter. He is an elderly fine looking man, always courteous in his manner to all; they have been coming here 9 years, his wife is also a fine looking dignified, but very pleasant woman. She has now to go about the house in a wheeled chair- there is a very smart looking lady who has to go on two crutches- we find she is the wife of Lyman Beecher Stowe who wrote the life of his

title: hsc0941_04
transc: a long time before any place was found for us, and when we were fixed, our situation was quite the reverse of agreable, for right opposite to me were 3 asdisagreable common looking men, with very red faces, proving that their common beverage was something much stronger than water, and so very near me thatI could not raise my eyes without seeing them_ the motion of the car is veryunpleasant to me, the jolting of a [?]essey waggon being delightful in comparisonso that after trying this route, I should much prefer the old road with allits tediousness_ I was very much surprised while waiting to get into the carby Effingham Buckley coming up to me + shaking my hand_ he was takingHannah to Philadelphia to see her mother and I was glad to hear we should havesuch an agreable addition to our party when we should get to Bordentown_They were without any companions and Hannah greeted me very cordially whenwe met on board the steam boat_ she looked beautiful + Eff was the picture ofhappiness_ Hannah said she was delighted with New York_ the city, its enhabitantsthe family she was connected with, even the water my dear, she was becomingto use her own words "exceedingly fond of," all was enchanting_ I was amused with her enthusiasm and thought to myself, "so much for being young, lovelyand beloved"_ + only 2 months married_ what will she say some 10 years hence, thinkest thou, cousin? She sayeth also that if she was notthe happiest creature in the world shew would be the most ungrateful onefor that every thing that could be imagined has been done by parents + friendsto make her love her new home_ and certainly they have suc[hole in letter]most completely and I ventured to express a fear that there [hole in letter]danger of old friends being superceeded by new ones, which I did [hole in letter]altogether like_ tears came into her eyes at this suggestion + the answer was "no! no! there is room enought for all"_ She enquired very particularlyabout Jacob + Lydia Morris and mentioned that Jacob was a veryfavorite cousin of hers and his wife very dear to her_ Eff + herself hadpassed Caroline Morris, Isabella Pennock and her brother on their way north in the morning_ One of the first things which I did yesterdaythough I should tell thee before, that we arrived at the wharf a fewminutes after two, and after making our way through unutterable noise+ apparently endless confusion to a carriage, in a very short time, I wassafely landed at my father's doors, and found upon entering my well beloved home, that my dear father + mother were quite well + expected me home_ Elisa + Lydia are still in the country, but I hope to see them next week when it will be really delightful to have our little bandonce more together again after the annual [seattering?] is over_ UncleJasper +Emma have not returned yet and I have not heard of anylimit ot their wanderings_ they like traveling much better than I door they would have been at hom before this time_ nothing particular has been heard from Caroline + Edward only that they have no thought of coming back soon.

title: hsc1536_05
transc: month, which I suppose she will now have to give up. She and Louise Thorne were both such close friends of Agnes that it would have been especially lovely to have had them here together.I am glad to hear such cheerful accounts from Aunt Clementine; she seems to be enjoying Minnewaska so much this year. I am going to write to her at once, this eve. I hope. We are at present having a delightful visit from Joe and Evelyn Morris, as you doubtless know. They are such cheerful agreeable company. Joe and I have been doing some fishing together and have had some pleasant times together even tho' rather unsuccessful. In my fishing trips around here I always keep thinking of Uncle Edgar and Squire Mills. They used to enjoy the sport so much, and of course went to the very same lakes and ponds that I now frequent. Did you know that Aunt Amy had given me Uncle E's gold watch for a birth-day present. She has been so good and kind to me and I so un-

title: hsc1515_06
transc: people hurry, but we hope to get both buildings completed before winter. I had hoped before writing to you again to be able to tell you that I had been to see your friends Carrie & Minnie Morris in Montrose, but although I have made some inquiry about them & find they have started a most successful boarding house somewhere behind the Jail, I wonder if it can be the Smiley House- I have not gone there yet.The Halseys are, I believe out at Hart Lake. They do not expect their aunts before the middle of August.You will want to know some of the home news, but I have little for you. The Awbury families are scattered as usual. The Evans boys, George & Ellie & one son at one end of the place- Grandpa Hartshorne, Sam & Marion & Cousin Frank at the other. Frank will

title: hsc1566_02
transc: the tale has become so long now, it wont all go into one letter. Then to get time for writing! I told Sister EPC I should have to adopt the plan of “five minutes daily writing” for even the evenings are now given up to reading Kingsley in connection with Covelly & the western coast. The house where he was born is nearly opposite the “New Inn”. No wonder he wrote about the fishermen and the sea.I might as well begin now to tell thee about Wells the ancient Fontanensis and sing a song o thripence[?] , three ladies that thee knows, (?) living in ancient chambers, all in the Vicars Close.Thee has to pretend thee knows the third lady Miss Ford, because she is a distant connection of Evelyn Morris Cope.

title: hsc1499_01
transc: Newport 8 mo 19th / 67My dear husbandI feel very much triedwith myself, for not having writtento thee yesterday, but left it until today, thinking, I might have more to tell thee, and now evening has comeand I have not accomplished it.Charles & Susan Wheeler called uponus particularly this evening, and of courseI could not leave the parlor untilthey left, 9 o'clk. Dr. & Mary have goneto pay a call at Murray Shipley's, this evening. our family is continually chang--ing, this evening Theodore Morris & wifeleft here for Niagara, going by the wayof New York. John Griffin has gone & someother gentleman. two more of RichardFellowes family arrived here on 7th daya son and daughter, the eldest onewith her husband have been herefor some days they are very agreablepeople, and very affable. I had

title: hsc1499_03
transc: borhood of 18th & spruce sts the water was not carried off &flooded the streets very much. The Schuylkill river rose veryrapidly 14 ft I think the paper stated and Manayunk wascompletely flooded so that the Lamp-posts were almost hiddenand in some instances the water rose above the lantern. Thecars on the Norristown road were stopped in consequence ofthe damage done, and on the Chesnut Hill road near Hilly'sdam the embankment was so washed away, that it willtake 300 cart loads of earth to repair it. Jersey is almost underwater this day. but there was not much of a [presher?] on theDelaware river, except at Richmond, where cellars were over-flowed. Fair-mount park was very much washed & thedam they say was like a young Niagara. On Fifth daylast the rain was the heaviest. fr'd Israel Morris had verygreat difficulty that day in driving home from meeting theCreeks & roads were so much overflowed with water, 4 hourshe was in going from Merion Meeting to his house. Rejina Pottsand her husband rent a house on Wister Morris'place. a creek near by was so swollen, that the water came into the cellar, and rose in the kitchen as high as the kitchen range, her barrel of flour floated way and she had

title: hsc1499_08
transc: They all expect to go to the White Mtsnext week. 2nd day I think. we shallleave here on the 30th and from all we hear from home, we ought  to bethankful we have had the childrenhere, tho' we have not had as fineweather as usual. More fogs, and some share of rain. I have justrec'd a letter form Susan (at dinnertime) she has been quite sick, but saysis on her feet again. she writes in goodspirits, says father wishes her to save herstrenght in order to write to us, and hwill do without the usual reading.I think Tommy mentions in his letter, to thee, that  the Fishermen on the Pt. have a reading-room at Goddards which MissGibbs I believe got up for them. It is a verygood thing for them, and Morris Walnwhen he was here with his sisters thissummer drew up a petition asking forsubscriptions to buy books for them. Itis to be laid on Mary Williams tableand if any one feels enough inerestin it to subscribe they can do so. Dr.told me, John Farnum, and some one else Morris Waln I think said they wouldsubsribe $10. and I thought most likelythee would give something if thee washere, therefore I propose doing so.Dear Frank. I fear thee will think

title: hsc1749_02
transc: desire of having a stone placed to mask Alexiss grave. but as I found it was necessary to speak to some of the Property Committee about it I waited till I could see Elliston Morris as I did not think it wd be best to put any responsibility upon Thomas. As Elliston has been away from home all summer I did not see him till yesterday. I find that in the new ground there is a clause in the deed of Trust forbidding “monuments”-- most of the Committee however consider than a plain stone, such as have been placed over some of the graves is not a monument-- & Elliston has so masked his sons grave. Nothing should be placed on it but the name-- & date of birth & death. Some have only the initials, but the other is usual. If this is what thee wishes please

title: hsc3150_03
transc: I suppose as Sam’ Morris was not at meeting today that he had carried out his intention of being at Jamestown-- Say what we may-- though silent meetings are better than meetings with poor preaching-- meetings where such ministers as Saml Morris are-- who never speak except with “demonstration of the spirit & of powers” are the best-- & I hope that he had a message for you & that thee was able to go.Justus Strawbridge was at meeting, having just returned from a two months trip abroad. He said he was pretty well, but he always seems somewhat sad to me. We had a little rain on Sixth day night but it is dry & dusty again-- The leaves are falling from the trees & some of the accords & chestnuts also.Tom had a letter from Alfred dated 26th Aug-- It contained nothing new except that they expected to stay at Le Picse till Sept 15th when the house is to close. So admonitions or advice will be useless. Tom sends his live & I do mine to Theo & Anna-- Tell Anna I received her letter & will heed her advice if way opens tomorrowAffty thy husband

title: hsc1498_02
transc: letter first, as I think it is much brighterthan the one from Liverpool, I hope whenEllis Yarnall arrives, thee will feel moreat home,and I felt glad to hear of thygoing to spend 1st day with Smith Harrisonas I should think it would be such a reliefto get out of London. I felt glad to beable to tell John Farnum that thee did notmention business matters in thy letter. asthey are very particular in their inquires after theeand have both desired their love to theewhen I write, still unless I had somethingdefinite to say I would prefer not knowing any thing. John Farnum & Elizabeth haveboth been very kind & attentive to us whilesister Elizy & her children staid here, theyinvited one of our daughters to room with Mary which was a great pleasure to themand we are on very easy termes. Yesterdaywas Mary Thurmon's birth-day & Charles & SusanWheeler gave her quite a party, invitingall the young people from [ell?] Williams &Jane Morris'to spend the evening with them.They had charaded & enjoyed themselvesvery much. had ice-cream &c. Mary hada handsome bunch of flowers presentedher, and altogether it was quite an affairfor the Point considering what a contrast itis to the gayity on the hill where they are having dinner parties & evening parties &c all the time.Clem Barclay has a cottage here, and they say he has a constant round of companyall the time, no rest whatever. It is said there are very few people here but I cannotrealize it, for in driving to Bateman's & aroundthe south shore by the new-road which is

title: hsc1498_03
transc: now nearly finished and will be a very hansom drive, wemeet a constant stream of carriages from the time we leave theSouth Shore, past Mr Fields' and all the way up the avenue to [Kay Dr?] far into the town. [barouchs?] driving 4 in hand, gentlemendriving tandem, pony chaises, ladies on horesback, all in rapidsuccession and I suppose nearly the same number the other waywhat must it be, when the place is crowded? We have a great manylodged out here. Yesterday one of Richard Fellow[e's?] daughters withher husband came from New Haven, and Israel Morris & wife thelast being guests of Jane Morris'. Last evening, when we came homefrom ride Edward Meyer & his wife came in, they had been allday from 11 o'clk in the morning coming from Narragansett Peer inthe ferry boat, having been becalmed without any dinner, they wreon thier way to Vancluse. After tea Hannah Williams told me, they had come on to Narragansett to take a farm which Mr Meryerhad purchased lately of [?] Hazard for 15000$ and when they cameto see found the house was not fit to live in and thought thefarm was not worth more than 4000$ when he saw it. The veryidea of buying a place of that kind without knowing more about it.They said thier goods were all in a vessel, now at Long Wharf,having left thier place on Staten Island, expecting to go to Narragansettand now they were going out to Tom Hazard to [blow?] him up I supposefor disciving them so as Meyer thought. H Williams advised themto have thier goods put in thier own house here at Newport wherethey would be safe at present. I saw them for a few minutes verypleasantly, Anna remembered them and Franky too. They seemed

title: hsc1498_05
transc: husband is travelling in New York Stateon business. Jacob Jones and Theodore Morris returned last evening from an excur-sion to Nantucket in a fishing smack sailed there in5 hours, attended a camp meeting, andsailed back yesterday; Tommy & the Dr.took out two parties in Geo Merritt's boatby moonlight. last 2nd day night wasperfectly beautiful and 3rd day they saidwas more lovely, as they had more wind.I did not go as I felt too timid anddid not wish to mar their enjoymentbut it reminded me forcibly of the lovelymoonlight sais thee & I took here togetheronce or twicethe summer before we weremarried. They had 15 or 16 in the boatall young people except the Dr. E Farnum,Mary Thurston & Myself went out on the pierto wait to see them come in. on 3rd day evethe moon was full and the bay waylike a sheet of silver not a sail to be seenso quiet & peaceful no sound but theplashing of the water against the row boatsmoored at the pierI could not help wishing for thee to enjoy it as I expectif thee had been here probably I shouldhave joined them. We saw a sail in the distance, but it passed up the bay, the freshbreeze was delicious & we walked up & downon the pier a little longer, when a few minpast 10 o'clk, we noticed a sail roundingthe light-house, and heard their voicessinging until thir boat touched out pier. Theywere all in tine spirits. Alfred enjoyshimself very much here with Tom Longstreth.thee remembers he was here last summer.he injoys sailing with Tommy & rowing toowith his uncle. Franky is well, but restless as

title: hsc2030_02
transc: ordeal. I sometimes think our old, inefficient Bridget wd. be better than some of the high toned, unwilling ones, I have met with, since living here.I was right sorry Edgar & Dr. Norris could not have gone together- the latter came to see E. about it- not being long since. all were absent but myself- however he remained to tea when some of the family returned. he made himself very agreeable & is less diffident than formerly. Last eve we had the pleasure of having Levi Morris' family to tea. They desired their love to thee & George. With this give mine to C. Bently & thank her for her interesting letter which I was glad to recieve. also give a great deal to dear Francis

title: hsc2030_07
transc: account) that she did not get off before. Cousin Levi, Naomi, Kate Morris & Miss [Nally?] only took tea with us last evening very pleasantly. Kate told us what a delightful visit she has had at Newport. Well I have no timem for more now as it is nearly time for E. to start. I could not let him go without a few words. I almost envy him. With muchlove thine trulyCarrie

title: hsc3194_03
transc: who could be there & we had short sermons from Saml Morris Geo Warner & Elizabeth P Smith & a prayer from Shober Kimber. I came away from the house with the boys & Cousin Wistar Brown & went to town with the latter in the trolley & called on Susan who sent word that she wanted to see me-- I thought she looked pretty well-- & she said she was much better of her ecsema. I bunched in with Tom & then went to the Asylum to meet a committee & drove home as usual-- And so endeth the days doings ofThy loving husband

transc: try to meet you in New York or Jersey City if you will let me know when. title: hsc0141_03a
transc: about twenty & a young girl who wore blue ribbons in her bonnet composing the balance. Last first day there was one plain man & three or four women in addition, but it's a weak body & looks as if it must yield to the force of circumstances.We very much miss cousins Anna & Mary Sharpless & I suppose will have to let Carrie & Nettie go this week & as we have word that Amy Yarnall & Agnes Harrison are not coming we shall be left to our own resources & the blues. Hurry up the painters, for we shall all want to get home. Theodore Morris' party are very pleasant people, but they spend most of their time at their cousins & when cousin Marmaduke leaves we hall only have Mary Williams & Job to exersise our own

title: hsc0141_04a
transc: sensational faculties upon unless some new arrivals should turn up. Come at your send us on somebody.The baby has been looking very yellow today & not so bright as a [s---] which concerns your mother a good deal, but I hope she is not going to be sick. We are giving her a little [calomel] & if she does not seem better tomorrow will get the Dr. to see her. Dr. Cheston Morris has been vacinating Theo. Morris baby & if he comes here tomorrow we will call on him in preference to Dr. King.Tom is very much afraid you'll forget his birthday. He will be ready for his presents either on his birthday or when he comes home which ever suits you. The painter was going to send us home patterns of painting for the parlors walls. Do you know why he has not done it? I don't know why Anne should want the kitchen tables painted. I was in hopes you had got a new

title: hsc0141_07a
transc: Disagreeably then in a religious matter & I cannot imagine how our friends from Philada. can stand a whole summer of such preaching as we have heard in the old meeting house. The little meeting is satisfactory in that respect, but half a dozen people must be more jealous than there appear to be to hold a meeting to much advantage.Dr. Morris says he will pay Tom his last visit tomorrow, as there is nothing to be done but to go on as we are doing. He is rather more discouraging in his anticipations than any doctor we have seen so far. Say Tom will be doing well if he has a sound leg in two years. But I dont believe in such a doleful prognostications. Dr. M. has not seen enough of Tom to judge though we think he seems to know what he is about & are very glad we have been able to call upon him. But I do not think he ought to have held out such a prospect to Tom. Luckily I do not think Tom took notice of what he said.Is aunt Sue in on the 15th? The

title: hsc0181_02a
transc: cool for summer the roads free from [----] & the horses willing to go. Thomas & Eliz.th & Mary staid [at] Sam Morris's to dinner. Dr. Rhoads was there having got back from his visit to the Indians the day before. He looked & said he was well & appeased to have had a more satisfactory visit than I think he feared he should have. He was to take tea tonight at Frank Stokes's with his sister [--------] & Chellie & I were asked to meet them - but Chellie was not willing to leave the baby & couldn't take her & I was not able to leave my rheumatism & wouldn't take it so she & I took a solitary rea. Carrie & Katie having gone up to Uncle Toms. These young people appear to have a pretty nice time - I don't know what they may do in the mornings but when I'm at home they are generally out on the [-------] lawn. Eddy stew

title: hsc0223_01a
transc:
Awbury 7 mo. 10. 1884

Dear Lillie
After meeting this morning I paid thy Germantown bills in proof of which I submit the receipt. The meeting was small as usual (at this time of year - but as usual also good. We had sermons from Dr. Rhoads & Saml Morris. Dr. R's recalled the conversation we had on the personality of the devil. He spoke of our wrestling not only with flesh & blood - our fleshy lusts & evil inclinations - but against the makers of the darkness of this world - spiritual wickedness in high places & how we felt at times the tremendous power of the devil so overpowering that we would despair of being able to stand against it if we did not

title: hsc0216_02a
transc: when we were at Montrose two years ago - only now I follow instead of precede Saml Morris's examination which is more satisfactory - as though I like it very well; I should hardly have ventured to recommend it to so [----ical] a set of readers as our Germantown friends. [Munger] is an advocate of what he calls the "new Theology" & is according to my view orthodox - though I suppose people who find fault with Fredrc Robertson & Bushnell will find fault with him. However Saml Morris likes him & I think orthodox churches generally will in a few years accept these views though now they appear in some points

title: hsc8016_03
transc: her. She now lives with the daughter that married M. Browns coachman. Thy now live or rather did yesterday on Morris St but were going to move today round upon Queen St No 413 (I think). Amelia said since wriitng to thee she had concluded she would go and clean house for thee. Moses Brown was going today to Lake George and going to take the coachman with him and her daughter had to move and would be alone so she said she thought she would not take a place just yet. She tacked[?] a great deal a steady stream and somehow I was not as favorably impressed with her as formerly. I suppose she and Lena will be on hand on second day to commence to clean. Last evening Henry was up to tea he has got

title: hsc6044_05
transc: begins when sister Ellie leaves us, then the net night Ellie Emlen, uncle Thomas & Sam go, and we shall be left with Mary as our only visitor until Agnes and Frank arrive, unless we can persuade Evelyn Morris to come to us. The latter is now at Newport staying with her aunt Miss Paul, but she has promised to come to us some time soon. Tell, my dear little Margaret, that this is why I felt lonely when J & I were here alone with Ernest & Harold. It seemed so unnatural to have this house, which is usually so full, so deserted

title: page 7
transc:
the cope evans family papers digitization project 5
In 2002, through the generous support of
the SNAVE Foundation led by J. Morris
Evans ’43, Haverford began to digitize the
Cope Evans Family Papers as a pilot project
for the creation of a digital library to serve
the Tri-College Consortium (Bryn Mawr,
Haverford, and Swarthmore Colleges).
The digital library would be the online
home for the three schools’ unique objects
such as manuscripts and photographs.
The process of getting the Cope Evans Family
Papers online was labor intensive. Each letter
was read multiple times to discover who wrote
the letter, to whom it was sent, and what
people and places were discussed in the letter.
The people referenced in the letter were
researched to make sure the correct person
was credited in a consistent manner through-out
the collection. Each letter was then
scanned and about a third of the letters were
completely transcribed to aid researchers.
Specific subject headings were assigned to
the majority of the letters using the same
controlled vocabulary list used by the Library
of Congress. Finally the letters were uploaded
to the Web.
To get the project off the ground
Haverford College Special Collections
hired Claire McGuire as Digital Archives
Fellow. One of Claire’s first assignments
was to determine what back-end database
software would power the Tri-College digital
archive. After researching and testing many
alternatives, Claire recommended the use
of CONTENTdm, a widely-used software
package in the cultural heritage community
for creating digital libraries. Claire trained
librarians throughout the Tri-College Con-sortium
to use the software and assisted in
the setup of many of the early collections in
addition to the Cope Evans Family Papers.
The website to present these unique materials
was coined Triptych (http://triptych.bryn
mawr.edu). Also during her tenure, Claire
oversaw our first set of student workers and
an intern, and wrote workflows and documen-tation
for the project.
In 2006, Karl-Rainer Blumenthal ’06 took
over the project as the new Digital Archives
Fellow. Karl developed graduated cataloging
levels to help accelerate the process of getting
the collection online. By the summer of 2007,
about 800 letters, or 27% of the collection,
were available online.
In 2007 the Library created my position,
Digital Collections Librarian, to oversee the
growing analog-to-digital and born-digital
content of Special Collections. One of my
main responsibilities has been to complete
the Cope Evans Family Papers digitization
project. Over the next year and half, I steadily
grew the size of digital production by hiring
new students and interns and supplement-ing
the necessary equipment. Meanwhile I
continued to improve the efficiency of student
training and the quality of the cataloging.
In 2008, six Haverford students and two
graduate students from Drexel University
participated in the project. Over 2,100 pieces
from the collection were published online
that year including 1,100 during the summer
break between semesters.
After years of careful scanning, cataloging,
and transcribing, the Cope Evans Family
Papers is now the largest collection in
Triptych with almost 3,000 digital objects
including letters, business papers, albumen
prints, and daguerreotypes. The successful
completion of the project is due to the hard
work of more than a dozen Haverford students,
three graduate student interns, two digital
archives fellows, and the Special Collections
librarians. The unwavering support and
encouragement of J. Morris Evans ’43 and
the SNAVE Foundation have been constant
throughout this endeavor.
David Conners
Digital Collections Librarian
about this project

title: page 17
transc:
of doing things underhandedly!” (September 1804 Mary Drinker Cope to Henry
and Francis Cope).
Letters preserve the paths of communication and relationships, and when they
are part of a school experience, they are a good way to learn how people thought
about and taught language. The Westtown Boarding School letters preserve the
aching homesickness, unabashed love, and currents of anxiety felt by children and
their parents, and they alert us to the profound work that we do as we try to give
children the best education we can. Moreover, they leave us the beauty of ordinary
people writing.
Elizabeth Kimball
Ph.D. candidate in English, Temple University,
Haverford College Quaker Collection Gest Fellow, 2008

Wedding Anniversary, December 1907. From Negative. Courtesy J. Morris Evans. Pictured left to right, standing:
Francis Hazen Cope, Margaret Y. Cope, Rachel Reeve Cope Evans, Harold Evans, Anna Cope Evans, Ernest Mervyn
Evans, Jonathan Evans, Edward Wyatt Evans, Theophilus Baker Stork, William Draper Lewis, Thomas Pim Cope;
seated: Henry Wilder Foote, Henry Wilder Foote, Jr., Eleanor Tyson Cope Foote, Elizabeth Stewardson Cope, Anna

Cope, Theodora M. Cope, Francis Reeve Cope, Jr.; floor: Henry Lewis, Alfreda C. Lewis W. Draper Lewis, Jr., Anna
Lewis, Francis Algernon Evans. Picture taken on porch of Francis R. Cope house. Appears in Tapestry Threads: Jonathan
& Rachel Cope Evans 1843 to 1911: Their Ancestors & Family, by J. Morris Evans, p. 79.
